text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with rosemary shortbread cookies
that's right looks to the contrary i'm
not really a big cookie guy which is why
we haven't done many videos on those in
the past and another thing i'm not a
huge fan of is adding unusual
ingredients to things that don't need
them just to make them different but as
you're about to see i'm gonna do both
those things and i think i have a pretty
good reason this is my favorite cookie
you're welcome people working on the
food wishes trivia game but anyway let's
go ahead and get started
on this incredibly delicious and
surprisingly easy cookie and one reason
it is so simple is it only contains a
couple ingredients which are butter and
lots of it flour and some sugar and that
is pretty much it we will however sneak
in a little bit of salt and a few drops
of vanilla as well as the aforementioned
rosemary and by the way could you please
stop staring at my wrinkled t-shirt
thank you so to get started what we'll
do is we'll pour our sugar over our
butter which by the way is not soft okay
I took it out of the fridge and cut it
up into this bowl about 15 minutes
before I wanted to start the recipe so
it's still pretty cold and firm and then
to this bowl we will also add a little
bit of vanilla extract we're also going
to put in a little bit of salt to make
everything taste better as well as about
two tablespoons of freshly chopped
rosemary and then what we want to do is
combine all this with the back of a
spatula or spoon because that butter is
still pretty cold and firm this is going
to take a minute to get going but you
can do it put your back into it and just
keep smashing and smearing and
eventually thanks to friction and other
physical phenomenon that butter is going
to soften up a little bit and you should
be able to smear and smoosh everything
together and end up with a mixture that
looks like this
and by the way that butter should still
be fairly cool to the touch alright so
while this would be easier with soft
butter I don't want you to use soft
butter use the cold butter it's going to
take an extra minutes but I think makes
for a better dough and once that's mixed
up we're going to lose the spatula and
switch to a floured hand to mix this so
I'm going to coat my fingers with the
flour and then we'll dump that flour
into our butter mixture and create the
rest of this dough by hand so what we'll
do is we'll start off with one hand and
we'll just kind of smush and smash
everything together just to get it
started I don't know maybe it's just me
but if I start with two hands right off
the bat I end up with flour flying all
over so I like to work it over a little
bit with one
first but once it gets going and it gets
to about this point we will introduce
our second hand and continue mixing and
basically we're mostly working with our
fingertips sort of rubbing everything
together and what we're watching for
here is for this to go from flowery
crumbs to buttery crumbs which should
look something like this which by the
way is only going to take a minute or
two and once it gets to this point and
you can kind of press everything
together into a dough ball we're going
to stop okay we don't need to mix it
anymore in the bowl because we're going
to continue to work the dough as we form
it so at this point let's go ahead and
transfer to our work surface and gather
everything together and then continuing
on with our trusty hands we're going to
press this into a disk and then into a
rectangle approximately a half inch
thick and by the way I would normally do
this on my stone countertop
unfortunately it's the same color as the
dough so I did it on my steel table
instead so you can see it better but
unfortunately there's a lot of give to
it so that's why it basically looks like
I'm working on a trampoline
but like I said we will press that down
into a rectangular shape but we're not
done we do want this pressed a little
thinner but it's hard to go any thinner
with our hands and get it nice and even
so what we'll do is we'll go ahead and
cover it with a piece of plastic and
then we have a couple options we want to
press this down to about a quarter inch
and if you want you can use a pan like
this or some other flat object to kind
of push it down and that can work very
well if you're on a solid surface but
because my table did have so much give
to it that really doesn't work out too
well for me so my preferred method is to
simply roll it with a rolling pin right
over the top of the plastic until we
have something relatively uniform and
approximately a quarter inch thick maybe
just a hair thicker but something close
to that
and once we've pressed and/or rolled
that into our desired thickness we will
take our bench scraper and try to get
this back into some kind of rectangular
shape and by the way feel free to trim
any uneven parts you can totally reroll
any excess dough but bottom line somehow
someway you want to end up with as close
to a rectangle as you can get at which
point we're ready to cut our cookies and
because as you know I'm such a stickler
for precision and perfection I'm going
to use this ruler so I can get perfectly
even straight cuts and know that is not
a new ruler and you see the white stuff
on there that looks like flour it's not
flour I think it's white out remember
when we had to use that with our
typewriters good times so we'll go ahead
and we'll cut our dough into nice even
strips and then
like I said if you have to trim a little
trim a little and you can roll those
scraps and make more cookies actually
save my scraps for an experiment that
you may or may not see at a future date
and then once we have our strips cut
we'll have to slice it the other way so
I measured the length which was 11
inches so 1/2 would be 5 and 1/2 and
then I didn't know how to divide a 5 and
a half by 3 so I just went ahead and cut
it by eye as you can see not even
remotely close to even but the good news
is it really doesn't matter because when
these are cooked they're going to look
amazing
and besides elyse are all the same width
and then once those are cut just take
your bench scraper and transfer those
onto a lined baking sheet I'm going to
use a Silpat but parchment paper will
work beautifully and then once our
shortbread cookies are trade-up
we need to S&F them which stands for
sugar and fork so first up we're going
to sprinkle the top of each one with a
little bit of granulated sugar and you
don't need a tremendous amount here just
a couple pinches per and then once those
have been sugared we're gonna go ahead
and give them the old polka polka with
the fork and by the way culinary school
it's not called the old polka polka it's
actually called docking and above and
beyond given them their signature
appearance they also will help these
cook more evenly and I want you to
penetrate each cookie exactly four times
so that we have 16 holes exactly and why
is that a big deal because twelves not
enough and 20 is too many so we'll
continue on until all our cookies have
been properly forked at which point
these are ready for the oven so let's go
ahead and transfer those into the center
of a 300 degree oven for approximately
50 minutes or until beautifully golden
and looking something like this
ok what we're shooting for is something
that looks exactly like a shortbread
cookie so the top should have a
beautiful light golden color and if we
turn one over which totally burned my
fingertips you'll see the bottom should
be a beautiful golden brown speaking of
burnt fingertips what I like to do is
leave them on the pan for about 10
minutes until they're cool enough to
transfer to Iraq where we will let those
cool completely
at which point our rosemary shortbread
cookies are ready to serve and like I
said in the intro I don't generally like
to add ingredients to things that are
already perfect but this just totally
works I mean if I blindfolded you and
gave you one of these cookies and did
tell you what was in it
the vast majority of people would have a
hard time guessing there was rosemary in
it oh they could tell something was in
there something wonderful and mysterious
but it's unlikely they would pick out
the rosemary
and besides the flavor I think the
texture of these things is just
absolutely perfect just the right
combination of crisping crumbly it's
still very tender and buttery but anyway
that's it
rosemary shortbread cookies incredible
flavor incredible texture and gorgeous
to boot I mean look at that look at it
all right that's enough so I really do
hope you give these a try head over to
